Case study

Building an effecient and transparent payment screen

Role

UX Research

Why this project is important to me

In 2013, The Motley Fool found itself receiving a number of customer service calls, with many concerned with the complexity of our online payment screens. A number of people were unsure of their subscription status and the duration of their commitment. Consequently, my team was assigned the task of investigating the matter, and embarked on a months-long research project aimed at enhancing clarity and ease for users.

We started by meeting with DevOps to access and analyze key data. Our internal data showed that the bounce rates were high for the payment screens. We could see that there was a problem, but we needed more information before we started designing solutions.

TL;DR:

Working with members to simplify payment

1 of 5

Discovery

Our customer support team noted an uptick in calls regarding confusion about our payment screens.

2 of 5

Findings

Our internal data showed us that our bounce rates were high for the payment screens. We began our research by looking for any connections.

3 of 5

Next steps

We surveyed existing members while listening to a number of customer support calls concerning the payment screens. Findings from these efforts inspire the first round of designs.

4 of 5

Validate

We attended an official Fool member event and performed user tests with existing customers. Transparency on subscription price and commitment were of paramount importance to users.

5 of 5

Build

Our design components allowed the team to iterate with ease and A/B test various solutions. In the end, our final design increased conversion by 40% while decreasing calls and bounces.

Discovery

After listening to live customer support calls, reviewing internal data, and meeting with stakeholders, we were able to gain a better understanding for what the payment form needed to do for the Fool as well as the user. Before starting design work, we knew:

  • We needed to balance business and user needs, and
  • The experience had to be secure and transparent.

After we distilled the findings, a research plan was generated and I started working on prototypes to user test with existing members at a local event.

Trello board to track and share research progress

Development

With a research plan and goals in place, we crafted a protocol for our qualitative interviews with members. The team was able to spend mulitple days speaking with members and facilitating user tests. Findings from those tests informed the next iteration.

A/B tests with new customers off existing marketing landing pages helped refine the final design. The study took 3 months to complete and impacted all payment screens on fool.com.

Notes from user tests to inform prototype iterations

Validate

The payment screens from our study increased conversion by 40%. Greater transparency on auto-renewal helped decrease customer service calls and bounce rates for the impacted screens declined by 20%.

Teaching compassion as a strong skill
